Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Geomorphology and Sediment Dynamics of a Tropical Montane River

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine bedload sediment transport of tropical montane rivers and estimate the potential impact of predicted climate change and dam development scenarios on their geomorphology. Tropical montane rivers are geomorphically dynamic and complex. They convey large-magnitude floods with the capacity to mobilize coarse bedload (gravels to large boulders) multiple times during a single rainy season. This doctoral dissertation research project will examine bedload distribution and flux, which play an important role in defining channel form in these systems and therefore are a proxy of system sensitivity. The doctoral student will pursue answers to the following research questions through an analysis of the Rio Pacuare, Costa Rica: (1) How does channel geomorphology vary going downstream in relation to local geology and sediment sources? (2) What are the sediment transport rates and annual yields of each reach? (3) Does downstream flux of bedload express local, reach, or system-wide geomorphic connectivity? (4) How will sediment flux change in response to predicted future climate change and impoundment (dam) scenarios? The Rio Pacuare is an appropriate stream for these kinds of analyses because it is free-flowing, relatively accessible, and is representative of other tropical montane rivers. The student will use innovative field techniques to map and characterize sediment and to create reach-scale sediment budgets. In addition to traditional survey methods, the Structure from Motion approach, which derives topographic data from multiple photographs, will be adapted for grain-size analysis and identification of grain mobilization to validate sediment transport estimates. Hydraulic and sediment transport models will quantify sediment flux to characterize system sensitivity to projected climate change and impoundment scenarios.

Research on tropical rivers is particularly important because demands on their resources (freshwater supply, hydroelectricity, ecology, and agriculture) continue to increase steadily, but relatively little research has been done on the geomorphology of these systems. The distinctive mix of field and remote sensing techniques used in this research will overcome some of the noted challenges of tropical river research, including difficult access, high sediment flux, rapidly fluctuating flows, and large-grain mobilization. Beyond expanding basic understanding of the dynamics of fluvial geomorphology, and especially the dynamics of tropical river morphology, this project may assist in the sustainable development, management, and conservation of tropical rivers by offering fundamental information that is usable by the public, scientists, resource managers, and policy makers. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research on the geomorphology of tropical rivers is particularly important, because demands on their resources (freshwater, hydro-electricity, ecology, and agriculture) are increasing steadily, while very little is known about their geomorphology or sediment dynamics. The upper Rio Pacuare in Costa Rica was selected as the study area (88 river kilometers long; Figure 1) because it currently is free flowing and contains a variety of geologic and hydraulic characteristics common in the steep montane tropics of Central America. This project maps and characterizes sediment and estimates transport rates to quantify sediment flux through the river and between river segments. A goal of the project is to estimate the sensitivity of sediment flux to projected climate change and impoundment (dam) scenarios. Data acquisition for this project required intensive field work in remote areas for a total of approximately ten months.

 

As the first study of this type on a tropical mountain river, this work provides findings that contribute to the scientific understanding of tropical river geomorphology. The Pacuare, like other tropical mountain rivers, is more hydrologically and geomorphically dynamic than mountain rivers in other parts of the world. Due to the intense tropical storm events that occur in the tropics, flows capable of mobilizing the Rio Pacuare’s gravel-to-large boulder sized bedload can occur multiple times during a single rainy season and coarse-grained sediment is transported downstream between river segments.. Tributaries and landslides also contribute significant sediment inputs at irregular intervals that can temporarily influence local sediment regimes. The preliminary findings indicate that channel form within a reach is relatively constant over multiple high flow events. Sediment transport models for each reach will show whether predicted future changes in flow will have a significant effect on sediment transport

 

To overcome some of the challenges of working and collecting data in remote tropical areas, this study creatively combined remote-sensing techniques with traditional river survey methods to obtain the needed data. Structure from Motion (SfM) is a remote sensing technique that creates geospatially rectified images and topographic models (DEM) by aligning matching points in dense photo sets and linking them to GPS points. This research utilized, for the first time, repeat SfM topographic surveys to validate boulder mobilization before and after high flow events. The resultant high resolution (~ 3 cm) models are capable of identifying boulder-specific mobility with a basic GIS change analysis done in ArcMap (Figure 2). SfM was also used to create high resolution (< 1m) geo-spatially rectified imagery and a DEM from aerial photos collected by helicopter over 75 river kilometers of the study area (Figure 3). This data is being used to map and measure geomorphic characteristics such as slope, channel width, bar distribution and area, etc. Accuracy was determined by comparing longitudinal profiles of the channel created from the SfM DEM, with two satellite-based DEMs available for this region. This comparison indicates that the SfM DEMs created by this research are more accurate than the satellite-based DEMs (Figure 4). The helicopter SfM data in the project have avoided some DEM inaccuracies evident in previous aircraft SfM projects. This information will benefit future efforts to create accurate high-resolution DEMs using SfM techniques and advance the study of rivers in remote, inaccessible terrain.
